material.mattext: Gilbert Grape has assumed the caregiver role for his entire family, including his intellectually disabled brother Arnie. According to McKnight & Kashdan (2009), how might this role affect his sense of purpose?
Caregiving provides automatic, healthy purpose
Externally imposed obligations can substitute for authentic purpose, creating meaning without self-concordance
Family responsibilities always enhance well-being
Purpose cannot develop in constraining environments

Correct!

McKnight & Kashdan distinguish between imposed obligations and self-concordant purpose. Gilbert didn't CHOOSE his caregiver role; it was imposed by family circumstances after his father's suicide. While caregiving provides structure and meaning, it lacks self-concordance - alignment with personally chosen values and goals. Gilbert has purpose-like structure without authentic purpose, which explains his dissatisfaction despite having clear direction.

The correct answer is B.

McKnight & Kashdan distinguish between imposed obligations and self-concordant purpose. Gilbert didn't CHOOSE his caregiver role; it was imposed by family circumstances after his father's suicide. While caregiving provides structure and meaning, it lacks self-concordance - alignment with personally chosen values and goals. Gilbert has purpose-like structure without authentic purpose, which explains his dissatisfaction despite having clear direction.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Too simple. Purpose quality depends on self-concordance, not just having direction.
  • C: Research shows obligations can be stressful when not freely chosen.
  • D: Purpose CAN develop even in difficult circumstances, but imposed obligations aren't the same as authentic purpose.

Gilbert's affair with Betty Carver appears to serve a psychological function. According to emotion differentiation research (Kashdan et al., 2015), what does the affair reveal about Gilbert's emotional processing?
High differentiation enabling strategic mood repair
Low differentiation - seeking stimulation to escape undifferentiated negative affect rather than addressing specific emotions
Successful compartmentalization of life domains
Adaptive coping through distraction

Correct!

Gilbert's affair appears to serve an escape function - seeking excitement to avoid his mundane, trapped existence. But he's not escaping a specific emotion; he's escaping general malaise. Kashdan et al. show that low differentiators seek broad escape mechanisms rather than targeted solutions because they can't identify what specifically is wrong. Gilbert can't articulate his unhappiness precisely enough to address it, so he seeks global stimulation instead.

The correct answer is B.

Gilbert's affair appears to serve an escape function - seeking excitement to avoid his mundane, trapped existence. But he's not escaping a specific emotion; he's escaping general malaise. Kashdan et al. show that low differentiators seek broad escape mechanisms rather than targeted solutions because they can't identify what specifically is wrong. Gilbert can't articulate his unhappiness precisely enough to address it, so he seeks global stimulation instead.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: High differentiators would target specific emotions with specific strategies, not seek general escape.
  • C: The affair creates complications that spill into other areas, suggesting failed compartmentalization.
  • D: The affair creates more problems than it solves, suggesting maladaptive rather than adaptive coping.

Arnie's intellectual disability is portrayed with specific behavioral characteristics (climbing the water tower, fixations, limited verbal ability). Which contemporary understanding would critique the film's portrayal?
All portrayals of disability are inherently problematic
The actor should have had an intellectual disability
The film focuses on caregiver burden rather than Arnie's inner experience, potentially reinforcing deficit-focused views of disability
Arnie is portrayed too positively

Correct!

Contemporary disability scholarship critiques portrayals that focus primarily on how disability affects caregivers rather than the subjective experience of disabled individuals. The film centers Gilbert's burden rather than Arnie's inner life. We learn what Arnie DOES but rarely what he FEELS or THINKS. This perspective potentially reinforces deficit-focused views where disability is primarily understood as a burden rather than a different mode of existence.

The correct answer is C.

Contemporary disability scholarship critiques portrayals that focus primarily on how disability affects caregivers rather than the subjective experience of disabled individuals. The film centers Gilbert's burden rather than Arnie's inner life. We learn what Arnie DOES but rarely what he FEELS or THINKS. This perspective potentially reinforces deficit-focused views where disability is primarily understood as a burden rather than a different mode of existence.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: Too absolute. Good disability portrayals exist and are important.
  • B: A valid critique but not the CENTRAL contemporary concern addressed here.
  • D: Arnie's portrayal includes challenging behaviors; the critique isn't about positive vs. negative.
Gilbert's mother has become housebound due to obesity following her husband's suicide. According to Gross (2015), her withdrawal represents which emotion regulation pattern?
Healthy situation selection avoiding triggers
Maladaptive situation selection - avoidance that provides short-term relief but maintains long-term dysfunction
Cognitive reappraisal of her circumstances
Expressive suppression of grief

Correct!

Gross distinguishes adaptive from maladaptive situation selection. Bonnie Grape's complete withdrawal from the world is situation selection taken to an extreme - she avoids ALL situations that might trigger emotional responses. This provides short-term relief (no confrontations, no judgments) but maintains her depression, obesity, and family dysfunction. She's not selecting situations strategically; she's eliminating situations entirely.

The correct answer is B.

Gross distinguishes adaptive from maladaptive situation selection. Bonnie Grape's complete withdrawal from the world is situation selection taken to an extreme - she avoids ALL situations that might trigger emotional responses. This provides short-term relief (no confrontations, no judgments) but maintains her depression, obesity, and family dysfunction. She's not selecting situations strategically; she's eliminating situations entirely.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: The avoidance is so extreme it prevents necessary life functioning. This is clearly maladaptive.
  • C: No evidence she's reinterpreting her situation; she's simply avoiding.
  • D: Suppression involves inhibiting emotional expression. Bonnie isn't suppressing emotion in interactions; she's avoiding interactions entirely.

When Arnie accidentally hits their mother, she slaps him - her first physical act in years. According to research on emotion (Feldman Barrett et al., 2001), what does this moment reveal about the relationship between behavioral inhibition and emotional experience?
Suppressed emotions eventually disappear
Physical immobility eliminates emotional reactivity
Extreme suppression does not eliminate emotional capacity; intense provocation can overwhelm even long-standing inhibition
Maternal instinct overrides all other responses

Correct!

Feldman Barrett et al.'s research shows that emotions remain even when not expressed or processed. Bonnie's years of immobility didn't eliminate her emotional capacity; it suppressed expression while emotions accumulated. The slap reveals that intense emotional provocation can break through even extreme, long-standing behavioral inhibition. The emotional response was always present; it just needed sufficient trigger to override the inhibition.

The correct answer is C.

Feldman Barrett et al.'s research shows that emotions remain even when not expressed or processed. Bonnie's years of immobility didn't eliminate her emotional capacity; it suppressed expression while emotions accumulated. The slap reveals that intense emotional provocation can break through even extreme, long-standing behavioral inhibition. The emotional response was always present; it just needed sufficient trigger to override the inhibition.

Why other answers are incorrect:

  • A: This is what the moment CONTRADICTS. If suppression eliminated emotions, she couldn't have reacted.
  • B: The slap proves this false. Immobility suppressed but didn't eliminate emotional reactivity.
  • D: This doesn't explain the mechanism. The question is about behavioral inhibition and emotional experience, not maternal instinct specifically.
